abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for this project are as
            follows: The project outcome is satisfactory, project
            sustainability is likely, the institutional development
            impact is substantial, and the overall performance of the
            World Bank and the Borrower is satisfactory. These are some
            of the lessons learned from this project: The old paradigm
            of developing a sector through the creation of parastatals
            is over; the promotion of strong professional associations
            can be the cost effective way to achieve expected results.
            Only a strong private and public partnership can contribute
            to the success of this new paradigm, where each partner has
            a role to play and particularly the Government, in building
            the right environment for this to happen. It takes longer
            than anticipated to "build" professional
            associations and make them financially viable. The project
            faced problems in removing constraints to boost supply and
            to meet an increasing demand resulting from aggressive
            external market promotion. If the project would have had a
            sound financial management ("transfer of capital"
            to the project's coordination unit), the flow of funds
            to the project could have been smoother and the problems
            generated by the inadequate existing financial management
            system and the delays in providing counterpart funds, which
            particularly affected this type of project, could have been
            avoided.  Research and extension should have been set as
            prerequisites to ensure increasing supply. Once the market
            has been identified, an immediate supply response is a key
            factor for the development of commodities. It hinges on a
            dynamic financial market ready to take risks. However, a
            common problem that the Export Promotion Project and similar
            projects being implemented in the sub-region faced, was the
            lack of adequate funding to beneficiaries'
            sub-projects. Future projects should not only concentrate on
            export of raw products but should also give equal importance
            to processing products with the perspective of increasing
            the value added, creating jobs in rural areas and ensuring
            sustainability. The issue in question is the Ivorian
            cashew-nut industry which may not survive if a fair amount
            of raw nuts is not processed in Côte d'Ivoire.
